race.name: BIGHORN GRAVEL
race.tagline: 10,500 feet of climbing, 11,000 feet of altitude, and zero champagne gravel - this is Colorado suffering at its finest.

length.explanation: 85 miles puts this firmly in the substantial category - not quite ultra territory but a full day in the saddle for most riders.

technicality.explanation: No champagne gravel here - primitive forest roads, singletrack sections, hike-a-bike mandatory, and descents that will have you white-knuckling. Organizers say you'll wish you were on a different bike at some point.

elevation.explanation: 10,500 feet of climbing including a single 18-mile grinder with 4,000 feet of gain. This is brutalist climbing - the kind that breaks spirits and builds legends.

climate.explanation: June in the Rockies means morning temps in the 30s F, midday pushing 80s F - a 40+ degree swing. Add unpredictable winds, moon dust, and possible afternoon thunderstorms. Layer game must be strong.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 7,130 feet and topping out above 11,000 feet where oxygen is 33% less than sea level. Sea-level athletes will suffer significantly without proper acclimatization - altitude sickness is a real threat.

logistics.explanation: Eagle County Regional Airport is just 2 miles away with direct flights from major hubs. Hotels available in Gypsum, Eagle, and Vail. Not remote access but June is peak season so book early.

adventure.explanation: White River National Forest, Colorado high country, alpine views above 11,000 feet. The scenery alone is worth the suffering. Remote backcountry that rewards the prepared and punishes everyone else.

prestige.explanation: Growing regional reputation but not yet at the Unbound/Crusher level. Attracts quality fields and serves as key prep race for bigger events like Leadville and Crusher in the Tushar.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with four aid stations on the 85-mile course, prize money for top 5, and organizers who care about rider experience over growth. They moved an aid station closer to the 11,000 ft high point for 2025.

experience.explanation: Finishers report 'pure stoke' and a huge sense of accomplishment. The combination of brutal climbing, technical terrain, and world-class views creates something memorable - this is proper type-2 fun.

community.explanation: Intimate event that grew from 300 to 500+ riders while maintaining welcoming vibes. Organizers explicitly not trying to be the biggest - focused on rider experience and community over scale.

field_depth.explanation: Attracts Olympians (Howard Grotts, Jessica Yeaton), LifeTime Grand Prix athletes, national champions (Lauren Stephens), and serious regional talent. Not Unbound-level depth but legit competition.

value.explanation: Prize money, quality aid stations, and a course that delivers maximum suffering per dollar. Positioned as a key training race for bigger events which adds strategic value beyond the race itself.

expenses.explanation: June is peak season in the Vail Valley - lodging costs escalate quickly. Budget options exist in Gypsum but most stay in pricier Eagle or Vail. Flying into Eagle County Regional keeps travel reasonable.

black_pill.title: THE BRUTAL TRUTH ABOUT BIGHORN GRAVEL

warnings.details: Starting at 7,130 feet and maxing above 11,000 feet means 33% less oxygen than sea level. Altitude sickness symptoms - headaches, nausea, dizziness, fatigue - can appear 6-24 hours after arrival. Arrive 3+ days early or pay the price.

10,500 feet of elevation gain including a single 18-mile climb with 4,000 feet of gain. That's ~123 ft/mile average with the hard stuff concentrated in leg-destroying chunks. Hike-a-bike sections are mandatory, not optional.

Forget your smooth crushed limestone dreams. This is primitive forest roads, deep moon dust, technical singletrack, and descents that destroy equipment. Your bike choice will feel wrong at some point - organizers guarantee it.

Up to 17 miles between aid stations in remote White River National Forest. You are 'solely responsible for your personal well-being' and must 'suffer the consequences' of your decisions. Rescue takes TIME out here.
Morning starts in the 30s F, midday hits 80s F - pack for a 40+ degree temperature swing. Afternoon thunderstorms possible. Unpredictable winds can turn climbs into survival exercises.
38mm minimum tire width or you're asking for trouble. Tire liners recommended. The rough descents and moon dust destroy equipment. Eric Brunner was leading in 2022 when a flat tire ended his race.
Olympians, national champions, and LifeTime Grand Prix pros in the field. Sub-5 hour winning times mean elite pace of 17+ mph with 10K climbing. Know what you're signing up for.

final_verdict.summary: Bighorn Gravel is a legitimate Colorado suffer-fest that punishes the unprepared and rewards those who embrace the brutality. The combination of 10,500 feet of climbing, 11,000+ foot max elevation, technical terrain, and remote backcountry creates an event that sits in the upper tier of difficulty for North American gravel racing.
final_verdict.who_should_race: Experienced gravel and mountain bike racers who want altitude prep for events like Leadville and Crusher, athletes seeking a challenging but intimate race experience, and anyone who finds 'champagne gravel' boring.
final_verdict.who_should_skip: Sea-level athletes unwilling to acclimatize, riders seeking smooth gravel roads, anyone without experience in technical terrain or hike-a-bike situations, and beginners - the 20-mile Gravel Curious option exists for you.
final_verdict.bottom_line: Not a bucket-list iconic event yet, but a damn good race that delivers maximum suffering per dollar with world-class scenery. Growing reputation, quality fields, and organizers who prioritize experience over growth. Give it a few more years and this could be Tier 1 territory.
